I agreed with you on one point and only disagreed with your opinion 
toward the American military.  The purpose of the advertising 
campaigns are to get peopel to join.  You may be right that they 
aren't completly seperate.  While they may also convince others that 
the military is a good thing that is not their primary purpose.  What 
really justifies the military is the contingencies we are involved 
in, the honorable behavior of the men and women who serve, and the 
family members/friends who support the U.S. citizen soldiers in 
service.  I don't believe that congress has ever voted the military a 
payraise because some constituant wrote their congress person, who 
was so completely moved by a commercial.  "Dog gonnit, that Army of 
one thing is pretty snappy.  The military needs more money.  I'm 
writing my congressman."  Supporters of the military have been: those 
who have served themselves, those who have family or friends serving, 
or those who wish they could have served.

Now don't get me wrong, I'm not attacking YOU.  You have valid points 
and I did agree that early Japan may have attempted to justify the 
samurai class by changing their role.  You are entitled to an 
opinion.  In this case, I think I may be closer to the issue and may 
be more informed.  I have not based what I told you purely on 
speculation.  I know how some of the money is budgeted and why they 
use it a certain way.  Any communication may serve multiple purposes 
but not all those purposes were the driving factor for creating the 
communication.  You believe that the military advertises to get more 
money.  It doesn't hurt my feelings that you think that.  In some 
round about way, the military may get more money.  But the purpose of 
those advertising campaigns is to recruit.  I don't know if it could 
be more obvious, since the end of those commercials tell you to 
contact a recruiter not a congress person.

Back to the topic.  Samurai didn't have to worry about advertising 
campaigns and raising money from the public.  They were in the 
samurai class.  They didn't need more people in it and they didn't 
require the support of the general public to get paid.

Brandon

said there wasn't. But the need is greater or lesser at any given
